title: 3D-printed models for catchment groups
text: Have you found your way here because you‚Äôre part of a catchment group and interested in a 3D-printed topographic model of your catchment? If so, you‚Äôre in the right place.

title: 3D-printed models for catchment groups
section: What‚Äôs the point in a 3D printed model?
text:
What‚Äôs the point in a 3D printed model?
In a previous post, I described these models as a ‚Äútangible, miniature representations of the landscape that you can hold in your hands.‚Äù They‚Äôre definitely not going to change the world, but they might serve as a conversation starter as you gather around the table to talk about your environmental goals and aspirations.



Koukourarata / Port Levy, Te Roto o Wairewa / Lake Forsyth, Te Waihora / Lake Ellesmere


These models offer a less abstract view of the landscape compared to a 2D paper map, focusing on elevation to reduce distractions. For visual thinkers, they can reveal connections and scales otherwise only visible from a helicopter.
By mapping the entire catchment, the model embodies the concept of Ki uta ki tai‚Äîa te ao MƒÅori perspective on integrated, indivisible land and river management, from the mountains to the sea.
And they‚Äôre just damn cool.

title: 3D-printed models for catchment groups
text:
How big are they?





Puketoi FMU made up of Akitio, Owahanga and Wainui catchments






Puketoi FMU assembled



My standard sized model is around 200mm long. This is a good size to hold in your hand or pass around.
If you want a bigger model, my printer can print up to ~300mm long in a single printed block. If you want larger than this, I can print multiple blocks which are either glued together or snap together with a dovetail joint. This is a bit more work, but it‚Äôs definitely possible.
Another option is to print multiple sub-catchments separately, the largest of which can take up the maximum size of the printer. If these sub-catchments are printed at a common scale, they should fit together like a jigsaw puzzle.

title: 3D-printed models for catchment groups
section: What‚Äôs this going to cost me?
text:
What‚Äôs this going to cost me?
Option 1: If you have access to a 3D printer through your local library, makerspace, or community, I can assist you with making an .STL file that you can print yourself.
Option 2: Due to popular demand, I can also now offer to 3D print these models for you. Some people can‚Äôt access a 3D printer, want a multi-colour model, or simply want a ready-made product without the hassle. I‚Äôm happy to print one of my designs for your group (or multiple copies if your group‚Äôs members want their own).
Pricing is heavily discounted for catchment groups and mainly designed to cover my consumable costs. Commercial-grade 3D printers don‚Äôt come cheap, and I‚Äôve got other direct costs like filament, power, and maintenance. One of these models typically ties up my printer for 8-12 hours.





Otama


I can provide an exact quote, which will depend on the size, complexity, etc. But for indicative pricing, expect in the $50-$100 range per model.
Option 3: If you‚Äôre not a catchment group or simply want one for your personal use, discounted pricing doesn‚Äôt apply. However, I‚Äôd still love to make one for you! In fact, the more paying customers I have, the more non-profit groups I can support. Please get in touch and I can provide a quote based on the complexity of the design.
I‚Äôm located in Christchurch and can post anywhere. Please allow 2-3 weeks lead time.





Upper Ruamahanga

title: 3D-printed models for catchment groups
section: I Want Something Completely Custom‚ÄîCan You Do That?
text:
I Want Something Completely Custom‚ÄîCan You Do That?
Probably! Get in touch and let‚Äôs figure it out. Some requests I‚Äôve already had include:

Larger prints comprised of multiple blocks
Commercial projects for businesses or councils
Personal requests for individuals
Preparing files for laser cutting or CNC routing
Sub-catchments that fit together like a jigsaw puzzle

title: 3D-printed models for catchment groups
section: Okay, I want one. How does the process work?
text:
Okay, I want one. How does the process work?





Ruakituri


Fantastic! I‚Äôm here to help make this a reality. Here are the steps to consider:

Location: The catchment must be in New Zealand. Anywhere in New Zealand is fine, but very small catchments may require LiDAR data, which isn‚Äôt available everywhere.
Define your area of interest: This doesn‚Äôt have to be a hydrological catchment. It can be a square, circle, sub-catchment, FMU, or multiple catchments. Any contiguous boundary works.
Obtain a shapefile: It‚Äôs easiest if you can provide a GIS shapefile (.shp) of your area of interest. Otherwise if it‚Äôs a catchment, I can likely derive this for you.
Get in touch: Fill out this Google form:



Loading‚Ä¶

title: Welcome.
text:
At KƒÅkƒÅp≈ç Industries, we bring the beauty of the natural world into your hands. Using cutting-edge 3D printing technology, we create physical cartographic models, specialising in 3D topography and bathymetry that capture the stunning contours of our landscapes.
Whether you‚Äôre an environmental organisation, regional council, educator, or outdoor enthusiast, our models are perfect for showcasing terrain, visualising catchments, or simply celebrating the land we call home.
Founded in Aotearoa New Zealand by Isaac Bain, our mission is to make geography tangible‚Äîone layer at a time.
Explore the land like never before. üåø Discover our models today.

title: About
text:
KƒÅkƒÅp≈ç Industries (NZBN: 9429052266102) was founded by Isaac Bain through his passion for turning landscapes into tangible works of art. Based in ≈åtautahi / Christchurch, New Zealand we specialise in creating physical cartographic models, with a focus on 3D topographic elevation models that bring the contours of earth to life.
Our models blend precision and creativity, making them perfect for environmental education, community engagement, and unique d√©cor. By combining Isaac‚Äôs background in environmental science and data visualisation with advanced 3D printing technologies, we deliver products that are as accurate as they are stunning.
We‚Äôre inspired by the kƒÅkƒÅp≈ç, a native and endangered New Zealand parrot known for its resilience and unique charm. Like its namesake, KƒÅkƒÅp≈ç Industries is dedicated to innovation and preserving the connection between people and the natural world.
Let us help you hold the land in your hands. üåè
